subject: Re: [junit] junit on large scale

messageBody:
Mike Clark wrote:

>
> On Jun 6, 2004, at 9:53 PM, Curt Sampson wrote:
>
> > It seems to me little effort at all to create an appropriate
> > MockBigObject, if you set up your system right. Let's say your
> > doSomething looks like this:
> >
> > public void doSomething(BigObject biggie) {
> > String s = biggie.getStringValue();
> > int i = biggie.getIntValue();
> > if (s == null && i == 0)
> > biggie.setResult(true);
> > else
> > biggie.setResult(false);
> > }
> >
> > Test it with:
> >
> > BigObject mock = new BigObject() {
> > public String getStringValue() {
> > return null;
> > }
> > public int getIntValue() {
> > return 0;
> > }
> > public void setResult(boolean result) {
> > assertTrue(result);
> > }
> > }
> > objectUnderTest.doSomething(mock);
>
> Yes, I agree that this can be a powerful and effective mocking
> technique.
>
> Sometimes I find it's just too easy to create a mock. I want to first
> answer the question: "Does this method need to take BigObject as a
> parameter?" If the answer is yes, then answer: "How do I mock
> BigObject?" I have to force myself to ask the first question; the
> second question seems to want to be the first question.

However, in this particular example, doSomething() displays some pretty
strong Feature Envy and probably ought to be moved to BigObject itself,
which may remove the need for a mock. :)

> > The secret to mocking, IMHO, is to make mocks that do the bare minimum
> > necessary to test the functionality in question, rather than trying to
> > make ones that actually look or act anything like the real object.
>
> Great point!

This is why I like jMock (dynamic mocks in general): it forces me to
think about request/response pairs, rather than the logic I need to get
the right response to the right request. All return values are hardcoded.
